awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Supporting Massive Wireless Connections in the Internet-of-Things (IoT) with Multiple Zadoff-Chu (MZC) sequences
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, a novel wireless Low Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) technology, referred to as MZC, for Multiple Zadoff-Chu, will be designed. LPWAN is a crucial component in Internet of Things (IoT), which will improve everyday life and business efficiency. IoT depends on LPWAN technologies to maintain connections to the devices, which face unprecedented challenges, because the communication range may be long, the number of devices may be very large, and the devices may rely on a single battery for years. MZC will offer significant advantages over existing solutions in network capacity, speed, communication range, and power consumption. Preliminary experimental results show that MZC outperforms LoRa, a leading LPWAN technology, using less than one-eighth of the bandwidth resource, as well as much lower signal power, which suggests that MZC will achieve over 8 times the network capacity and a longer communication range or a longer battery life. Given its potential benefit, MZC will become a very strong contender and may potentially reshape the LPWAN technology landscape. This project will advance the knowledge on fundamental issues in wireless communication and networking in the very low Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) regime. Results obtained in this project will be used in related classes. Undergraduate students and students from underrepresented and minority groups will be actively recruited.
    
MZC is motivated by the excellent properties of the Zadoff-Chu (ZC) sequence, which have been used and proven in LTE (Long Term Evolution) networks.  In MZC, a transmitted ZC sequence will generate a peak at the receiver, the location and phase of which can be used to modulate data. A number of tasks will be investigated, with the goal of optimizing the design at every layer, and implementing a functional prototype to facilitate the transition to practice. In particular, first, the physical layer will be further optimized with better methods and error correction codes to cope with signal degradation and error caused by practical issues such as synchronization error and carrier frequency offset. Second, a hybrid Medium Access Control (MAC) layer will be designed, which has both a scheduled access method and a random access method, the latter based on a novel scheme called Peak Location Division Multiple Access (PLDMA). Third, core problems in the networking layer will be solved to maximize the overall network capacity, exploiting the low interference among ZC sequences with different roots, which allows nodes to use the same frequency channel without causing significant interferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, Zhenghao Zhang and his students designed novel wireless technologies for Low-Power Wide-Area Networks (LPWAN) that connect a large number of devices for applications such as smart metering, smart lighting, and livestock monitoring. The focus was to improve the network capacity, which has become the bottleneck of most LPWANs as the network size grows, where the network capacity is the amount data the network can receive reliably from the nodes in a given time period. The new technologies have been demonstrated in real-world wireless networks with over-the-air transmissions from multiple nodes and have been further tested with extensive simulations with challenging wireless channel models, which show that the improvement of network capacity is 200% or more over the state of the art. As LPWANs are expected to continue to grow at a fast rate reaching hundreds of billions of dollars in market value within the next 10 years, the new technologies designed in this project will likely generate significant impact and improve the quality of everyday life.

 

The main result of this project is the design and implementation of a long-range wireless technology called ZCNET, which has been compared with other main LPWAN technologies, such as LoRa, RPMA, and Sigfox, and was shown to achieve gains of 200% or more in network capacity. The key novelty of ZCNET is to modulate data with the Zadoff-Chu (ZC) sequence, which is capable of both reaching long communication distance and delivering high network capacity, because the interference from other nodes in the network can be effectively and efficiently cancelled. Nodes in the network enjoy low complexity because the data modulation and packet transmission policy with ZCNET are very simple, while the main computation is shouldered by the gateway in the network. ZCNET has been published in IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking, a top journal in the field of network communications and has been patented in October 2023.

 

In addition to ZCNET, the project also generated other results in the field of LPWANs, most of which were driven by the need to fully understand the competitors of ZCNET to conduct fair and in-depth comparisons. One of the main players in the field of LPWANs is LoRa, which is known for its long communication range but suffers from low network capacity. To reveal the full potential of LoRa, Zhenghao Zhang and his student designed a novel receiver for LoRa networks that can decode collided LoRa packets, which has been published ACM CoNEXT 2022, one of the top conferences in the field of network communications, and have made their code and packet traces public for the community. Zhenghao Zhang and his student have also designed a receiver for LR-FHSS, which is a newly emerged LPWAN technology, and have made their code and packet traces public for the community. They have also made their implementations of Sigfox and RPMA simulators publicly available.

 

Multiple graduate students have participated in this project and used this opportunity to work on various aspects of wireless networks, including waveform design, signal processing, real-time system implementation, and experimental evaluation, which prepare them to join the work force as engineers, researchers, or teachers. Students from minority and underrepresented groups have been actively recruited and some have participated in this project, such as three female graduate students.
